Graphical abstract N/S-doped mesoporous carbon supported Fe-N x sites are coupled with FeS@C core-shell nanoparticles, disrupting uniform electronic distribution of single-atom sites and significantly enhancing ORR activity for rechargeable zinc-air batteries. The development of efficient single-atom catalysts (SACs) for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) remains a formidable challenge, primarily due to the symmetric charge distribution of metal single-atom sites (M-N4). To address such issue, herein, Fe-N x sites coupled synergistic catalysts fabrication strategy is presented to break the uniform electronic distribution, thus enhancing the intrinsic catalytic activity. Precisely, atomically dispersed Fe-N x sites supported on N/S-doped mesoporous carbon (NSC) coupled with FeS@C core-shell nanoparticles (FAS-NSC@950) is synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction and subsequent pyrolysis. Due to the presence of an in situ-grown conductive graphitic layer (shell), the FeS nanoparticles (core) effectively adjust the electronic structure of single-atom Fe sites and facilitate the ORR kinetics via short/long-range coupling interactions. Consequently, FAS-NSC@950 displays a more positive half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.871 V with a significantly boosted ORR kinetics (Tafel slope = 52.2 mV dec−1), outpacing the commercial Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.84 V and Tafel slope = 54.6 mV dec−1). As a bifunctional electrocatalyst, it displays a smaller bifunctional activity parameter (ΔE) of 0.673 V, surpassing the Pt/C-RuO2 combination (ΔE = 0.724 V). Besides, the FAS-NSC@950-based zinc-air battery (ZAB) displays superior power density, specific capacity, and long-term cycling performance to the Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB. This work significantly contributes to the field by offering a promising strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of SACs for ORR, with potential implications for energy conversion and storage technologies. Keywords Fe-N x sites Core-shell FeS@C Synergistic interactions Oxygen reduction reaction Zn-air battery 1 Introduction Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is the bottleneck process in many energy conversion and storage technologies, including metal-air batteries and fuel cells [1–3]. However, the extremely slow multiple-electron transfer kinetics of ORR limits the overall output of a metal-air battery. While noble metal-based Pt and Pd catalysts demonstrate benchmark ORR performance [4], their unaffordable cost, scarcity, vulnerability to methanol poisoning, and unsatisfactory long-term operational abilities in harsh electrolytes hamper their large-scale implementation. On the other hand, zinc-air batteries (ZABs) require electrocatalysts with bifunctional activity, capable of catalyzing both ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), but those aforementioned catalysts can catalyze ORR alone [5]. To use them in metal-air batteries, noble metal-based catalysts need to be coupled with other OER-active precious metal-based oxides, such as RuO2 or IrO2 [6–8]. However, the incompatible combination often results in underwhelming performance in ZABs. Therefore, it is highly significant and urgent to rationally design high-efficiency nonprecious metal-based bifunctional catalysts that can drive both ORR and OER at lower overpotential than the precious metal-based catalysts to achieve the optimal efficiency of ZABs. Among the nonnoble metal-based electrocatalysts, materials with metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N x -C) coordination sites, popularly known as single-atom catalysts (SACs), are currently receiving significant research attention due to their excellent ORR performance, tunable electronic states, and maximum atom utilization efficiency (100% in theory) [9–11]. Recent studies demonstrated that the Fe-N x -C catalysts with dominant Fe-N4 sites can significantly boost the ORR activity [12]. However, the uniform charge distribution around the metal atom of M-N4 sites results in an unfavorable free energy change for the oxygen adsorption and desorption kinetics, greatly diminishing the kinetic reaction [13,14]. This issue can be resolved in two ways. The first strategy involves replacing one or more coordinated nitrogen sites of M-N4 with other atoms, although achieving specific atom replacements in single atom sites is highly complex [15–17]; the second strategy involves incorporating heteroatoms [18] or hetero-nanoparticles into the supporting carbon network [19–22], which can improve the intrinsic activity by effectively modulating the surface electronic states of M-N4 site via short/long-range coupling interactions. It should be noted that designing a synthesis strategy capable of introducing both N and S heteroatoms into the targeted material can accomplish the latter discussed strategy. Incorporating high (N = 3.04) and low (S = 2.58) electronegativity elements can effectively induce charge distribution in graphitic carbon (C = 2.55), tailoring the electronic microenvironment of M-N4 sites for facilitating ORR kinetics [23]. Notably, when S is used as the heteroatom during materials fabrication, its strong coordination ability often results in the formation of metal sulfides, in addition to S-doping in the supporting network [24–26]. The inclusion of metallic species in SACs is generally considered undesirable due to overshadowing the active M-N x sites and agglomeration issues. Recent studies have demonstrated that core-shell metallic species, protected by a graphitic layer, can be immobilized and regulated to prevent agglomeration [27]. This protective graphitic layer not only maintains their stability but also influences the microenvironment of M-N4 sites, further optimizing their electrocatalytic performance [28,29]. Notably, the M-N x sites of single-atom catalysts are acknowledged as the active catalytic sites for both the ORR and OER when there are no other associated particles [30,31]. However, when SACs are combined with nanoparticles, identifying the active sites becomes more complex [20–22]. Notably, the recent study by Li et al. documented that the atomically dispersed Co phase is responsible for ORR and the associated nanosized Co boosts the OER [20]. Other noteworthy experimental and theoretical efforts by Sun et al. documented that the atomically dispersed Co sites initiate the ORR and catalyze the oxygen reduction to hydrogen peroxide (O2 → H2O2) stage and the associated Co nanoparticles facilitate the subsequent reduction to water (H2O2 → H2O) [21]. However, in most cases the core-shell nanoparticles were acknowledged as the surface electronic states modulator, instead of the direct active site. Despite tremendous progress in SACs fabrication in both N-doped and N/S-co-doped carbon supports, the systematic investigation of the influence of associated metallic species on the electronic configuration of M-N4 sites is still in its infancy. Additionally, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), crystalline porous materials with metal-organic species in their structures, offer potential as sacrificial templates to create N-doped porous carbons [32–34]. N-rich zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a sub-class of MOFs, have been extensively used for this purpose, yet the scarcity of alternative precursors remains a challenge [35–37]. Therefore, considering the above-discussed issues, a new MOF-derived N/S-doped material with rich Fe-N x sites and core-shell FeS@C nanoparticles has been developed. Owing to the inherited MOF-related advantages and the synergistic long-range coupling interactions between conductive FeS nanoparticles and Fe-N x sites within the N/S-doped carbon, as-prepared FAS-NSC@950 displayed remarkable bifunctional activity (being active for both ORR and OER). Specifically, FAS-NSC@950 demonstrates a significantly improved ORR activity, with a higher half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.871 V compared to the standard 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (E 1/2 = 0.84 V). Moreover, it requires a much smaller overpotential of 1.544 V to attain the benchmark 10 mA cm−2 current density (Ej = 10) for OER, outpacing the commercial RuO2 catalyst (1.564 V at Ej = 10). The remarkable enhancement in both ORR and OER activities results in a considerably reduced bifunctional activity parameter (ΔE = 0.673 V) for FAS-NSC@950, surpassing the standard Pt/C-RuO2 combination. As a cathode material, it exhibits a better open-circuit potential, high power density, higher specific capacity, and improved cycling stability in Zn-air battery applications, outpacing the commercial Pt/C-Ir/C-based battery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Anhydrous zinc(II) acetate (Zn(OAc)2), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC or trimesic acid), 1,10 phenanthroline monohydrate (Phen), ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4), ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (FS; FeSO4·7H2O), ferrous ammonium sulfate hexahydrate (FAS; Fe(NH4)2SO4·6H2O), sodium hydroxide flakes (NaOH), and absolute ethanol were purchased from Aladdin, Co. Ltd. Commercial 20 wt% Pt/C (ORR reference catalyst), RuO2 (OER reference catalyst), 20 wt% Ir/C, and Nafion ink were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Ltd. All the chemical reagents were used directly without any additional purification. Absolute ethanol and the distilled water were used for washing the materials throughout the investigations. 2.2 Synthetic approach 2.2.1 Synthesis of HUT-11 Zn-based HUT-11 was prepared using a slightly modified synthesis protocol, following the literature by Xu et al. [38]. Briefly, 0.42 g of BTC (2 mmol) was dissolved in an alkaline water-ethanol mixture (made up of 7 mL NaOH (1.0 M) + 15 mL water + 5 mL ethanol) by vigorously stirring at ambient temperature. To which, 0.395 g of Phen (2 mmol) and 0.44 g of Zn(OAc)2 (2 mmol) were added in a sequence and the stirring was continued for additional 30 min. The resulting reaction mixture was subsequently transferred to a Teflon lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 2 days. The as-obtained colorless crystalline sample (HUT-11 with Zn5(μ-OH)(BTC)3(Phen)4·5H2O coordination) was collected by washing with plenty of water. 2.2.2 Synthesis of HUT-11-derived electrocatalysts A two-step fabrication method was employed to synthesize electrocatalysts consisting of atomically dispersed Fe-N x sites and core-shell FeS nanoparticles. In the first step, a certain amount of HUT-11 (0.8 g) was dispersed in 2 mL of water, to which 120 mg of Phen (0.6 mmol) and 80 mg of FAS (0.2 mmol) were added in a sequence, ultrasonicated for 10 min, and stirred at ambient temperature for 30 min. The resulting mixture was lyophilized to obtain the solid sample. In the second step, the solid sample was placed in a quartz boat and carbonized at 950 °C for 3 h under a flowing nitrogen gas (heating rate = 5 °C min−1). The resulting black solid was treated with 60 mL of 0.5 M H2SO4 at 60 °C for 12 h, followed by washing with ample amount of water and being dried in an electric oven at 60 °C, and denoted as FAS-NSC@950. Similarly, FAS(0.1)-NSC@950 and FAS(0.3)-NSC@950 were prepared using 0.1 and 0.3 mmol FAS, respectively, while maintaining a constant mole ratio of FAS to Phen of 1:3. On the other hand, FAS-NSC@950 was further leached with 120 mL of 2 M H2SO4 at 80 °C for 48 h, and the FAS-NSC@950-AW sample was obtained, in which FeS nanoparticles were partially eliminated. Additionally, in view of realizing the NH3 gas evolution and its influence on morphology and the ORR performance, FS-NSC@950 was prepared by treating HUT-11 with FeSO4·7H2O and Phen reagents. Moreover, HUT-11 was treated with (NH4)2SO4 alone (0.2 mmol) in the above discussed method and the obtained sample was named as NSC@950. Similarly, HUT-11 was carbonized without any additional dopants and NC@950 was obtained. The information related to materials characterization has been provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterization Scheme 1 demonstrates a systematic fabrication approach for synthesizing Fe single-atom sites coupled synergistic catalysts by means of a sequential hydrothermal reaction, iron adsorption, and a carbonization method. Specifically, the HUT-11 microrod precursor was obtained by treating a Zn2+ salt with BTC and Phen ligands. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of HUT-11 confirm the successful coordination of Zn with BTC and Phen ligands (Fig. S1) [38], and the morphology analysis by scanning electron microscope (SEM) shows that HUT-11 exists as micrometer-sized and rectangular-shaped rods (Fig. 1 a). It should be noted that the coordinated Phen ligands provide the N-donor sites for feasible atomic distribution (M-N x ) of targeted metals during carbonization. On the other hand, the associated oxygen-rich BTC promotes the removal of carbon and hydrogen from the precursor in the form of CO2 and H2O, facilitating the formation of catalytically active mesopores [39]. Keeping this in mind, HUT-11 was then treated with the Fe-Phen complex in water and lyophilized to produce Fe-Phen@HUT-11, which was then pyrolyzed at 950 °C to obtain the nanoparticles coupled Fe SACs. It should be noted that the ferrous ammonium sulfate (FAS)-based Fe-Phen provided N and S doping into the material in addition to the Fe source, and the existing ammonium moiety can release NH3 gas and etch the material surface during pyrolysis to improve its contact with the electrolyte during electrocatalysis. More importantly, FAS adsorption can grow electrically conductive carbon nanotubes (CNT) during pyrolysis [40,41]. In addition, the powder XRD patterns of FAS-NSC@950 showed that the material has crystalline FeS nanoparticles (Fig. 2 a, JCPDS PDF#37-0477) [42], and the existence of FeS crystalline phase in FAS(0.1)-NSC@950 and FAS(0.3)-NSC@950 confirmed the obvious nanoparticle formation (Fig. S2). While, the pure HUT-11 by direct carbonization (NC@950) and carbonization after ammonium sulfate adsorption (NSC@950) delivered the pure graphitic carbon crystalline phase (Fig. S3). This experimental analysis suggested that the Fe and S elements present in FAS produce FeS nanoparticles in addition to the above-discussed unique features. SEM analysis clearly showed the distribution of ultrafine FeS nanoparticles in FAS-NSC@950, with an extensively etched microrod surface that developed a CNT network (Fig. 1b). It should be noted that the morphology of the HUT-11 did not undergo significant changes after high-temperature pyrolysis (Fig. S4a), whereas clear etching was observed in the ammonium sulfate-adsorbed sample after pyrolysis (Fig. S4b), without any CNT growth. This indicates that the presence of Fe catalyzed the growth of CNT in FAS-NSC@950. On the other hand, SEM images of FS-NSC@950 sample, prepared by treating HUT-11 with ferrous sulfate (FS)-based Fe-Phen complex, did not exhibit significant morphology deviation (Fig. S5), emphasizing the importance of ammonium moiety. Moreover, despite the presence of Fe, there is no CNT formation, confirming that both Fe and the ammonium moiety are essential for this unique morphology change [41]. On the other hand, the crystalline phases formed during pyrolysis differ between the samples treated with FAS and FS-based Fe-Phen, in addition to the considerable deviation in morphology. Specifically, FAS-NSC@950 consists of FeS nanoparticles crystalline phase in its XRD analyses, while FS-NSC@950 contains the crystalline phases related to Fe nanoparticles (Fig. 2a, JCPDS PDF#98-000-0258) [37]. This deviation in nanoparticles formation confirms that the ammonium moiety present in FAS can catalyze the iron sulfidation to produce FeS nanoparticle, in addition to surface etching and CNT growth. Besides that, the quantity of FAS used has a significant influence on the morphology because both the Fe and the ammonium moieties are important (Figs. S6–S8). Specifically, when small amounts of FAS are adsorbed, there are fewer CNTs and partially etched rods (FAS(0.1)-NSC@950). On the other hand, the increased FAS adsorption leads to the formation of broken rods with etched surfaces and extensively grown CNT networks (FAS(0.3)-NSC@950). Moreover, the nanostructure investigation by transition electron microscopy (TEM) analysis confirmed the existence of ultrafine FeS nanoparticles with diameters ranging from 10–30 nm on the surface etched microrods (Fig. 1c and Fig. S9a). It is noteworthy that, due to the simultaneous development of FeS nanoparticles and the CNT network, most of the nanoparticles were encapsulated by the nanotubes and the other nanoparticles located on the nanorod surface were also protected by several nanometer-sized graphitic layers (Fig. 1d–f and Fig. S9b and c). As a result, these FeS nanoparticles were not removed during acid leaching [43]. The presence of the protective graphitic layer allows these nanoparticles to remain in a fixed position without obstructing the exposure of active Fe-N x sites and prevents their agglomeration during electrocatalysis [14]. Recent studies also established that the Fe-N x sites associated with core-shell nanoparticles can display better ORR activity, owing to the induced asymmetric charge distribution via long-range coupling interactions [13,28]. The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images display a typical interplanar spacings of 0.175 and 0.21 nm, corresponding to the (300) and (114) crystal planes of FeS nanoparticles, and the graphitic layer displays the 0.34 nm lattice fringes, confirming the (002) plane of carbon (Fig. 1e and f) [43]. Besides that, the aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (AC-HAADF-STEM) investigation of FAS-NSC@950 endorsed the simultaneous existence of FeS nanoparticles and the densely dispersed Fe-N x sites (yellow circles in Fig. 1g and h). Additionally, HAADF-STEM and the corresponding energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping images clearly displayed a uniform distribution of Fe, S, N, C, and O elements (Fig. 1j–m and Fig. S10). Precisely, the uniform distribution of Fe and N elements confirmed the presence of Fe-N x sites throughout the material. In addition to that the dense accumulation of Fe and S elements in the large-sized bright spots region of HAADF-STEM image confirmed the existence of FeS nanoparticles (Fig. 1k and l) [24], and the uniform distribution of S throughout the material confirm the S doping in the material. Therefore, it can be realized that a small portion of iron has been trapped in the N/S-doped carbon as atomically dispersed Fe, and the remaining portion underwent sulfidation to become FeS [44]. It is important to note that the morphology and nanostructure of FAS-NSC@950 remained largely unchanged after thorough acid washing at high temperature (FAS-NSC@950-AW), which confirms the strong protective ability of the graphitic layer (Figs. S11 and S12) [24,28,45]. However, a few FeS nanoparticles on the microrod surface were removed, while the majority of nanoparticles embedded in CNTs remained unaffected. On the other hand, TEM analysis of FS-NSC@950 confirmed the presence of only a few Fe nanoparticles and no evidence of CNT formation was observed (Fig. S13), signifying the importance of ammonium moiety. It should be noted that the Fe nanoparticles in FS-NSC@950 lacked the protection provided by a graphitic layer, making them more susceptible to removal during acid wash. Furthermore, a typical lattice fringes with 0.21 nm interplanar distance, corresponding to (111) lattice plane of Fe, were detected in its HR-TEM, confirming the existence of Fe nanoparticles [37]. Moreover, the as-prepared samples were subjected to Raman spectroscopy and obtained two characteristic bands (D and G) of graphitic carbon [46]. Precisely, the D band appearing at ∼1343 cm−1 signifies the extent of defects formation in the graphitic carbon, while the G band appearing at ∼1580 cm−1 indicates the graphitization degree in the material [47]. Additionally, the I D/I G ratio, which represents the intensity ratio of the D and G bands, is a crucial parameter describing the level of defects in the material. In general, a higher I D/I G value suggests a greater presence of defects such as edge defects, hole defects, and the disordered carbon (conversion of unsaturated (sp 2) carbon into saturated (sp 3) carbon) in the material [48–50]. As shown in Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S14, the I D/I G ratio significantly increased from the sample carbonized without the ammonium moiety (NC@950, I D/I G = 0.85) to the sample treated with ammonium sulfate (NSC@950, I D/I G = 0.975) and to the sample treated with ferrous ammonium sulfate (FAS-NSC@950, I D/I G = 1.04). This indicates that the simple carbonization process enhanced the degree of graphitization (NC@950), while the treatments with ammonium sulfate and ferrous ammonium sulfate promoted the formation of defects in the material. However, despite the unambiguous existence of FeS nanoparticles, the characteristic Raman bands that correspond to FeS were not detected for FAS-NSC@950, possibly owing to its encapsulated structure. On the other hand, the sample treated with ammonium sulfate displayed slightly better I D/I G value than the ferrous sulfate treated sample (FS-NSC@950, I D/I G = 0.946), highlighting the importance of ammonium moiety. Interestingly, a slight increment in I D/I G (1.06) was observed for FAS-NSC@950-AW after acid leaching. This may be attributed to the formation of additional defective sites resulting from the leaching of a small amount of FeS nanoparticles (Fig. S14b). Moreover, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded in view of investigating the specific surface area (SSA) and the porous characteristics of the samples [51]. It is to be noted that the SSA of FAS-NSC@950 increased by almost three times (146.7 m2 g−1) compared to its precursor, HUT-11 (50.3 m2 g−1). In contrast, the other control sample, FS-NSC@950, exhibited a slight increment in SSA (72.2 m2 g−1) as its morphology underwent only minor changes from its precursor, HUT-11 (Fig. 2c). Moreover, the presence of a small hysteresis loop between the relative pressure (P/P 0) range of 0.5–0.8 and the significant N2 uptake at 0.8–1.0 P/P 0 indicated the mesoporous nature of FS-NSC@950 and FAS-NSC@950. The corresponding Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) desorption curves of FS-NSC@950 and FAS-NSC@950 displayed a sharp peak at 3.8 nm, suggesting that most of the pores have a diameter of less than 5 nm. Furthermore, all three samples displayed dense pores with diameters below 50 nm, indicating the mesoporous nature of these materials (Fig. S15). The high SSA detected for FAS-NSC@950 is expected to expose a vast number of catalytic sites, and the hierarchical mesopore structure offers catalytic advantages by facilitating mass transport during catalysis [52]. Additionally, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis of FAS-NSC@950 confirmed the Fe–S bonding (peak at 622 cm−1), S-doping (C–S peak at 535 cm−1), and N-doping (C=N peak at 1645 cm−1) in the material [53], while the peaks corresponding to HUT-11 have almost disappeared, confirming the complete transformation into the desired material (Fig. S16). Subsequently, the surface chemical composition of FAS-NSC@950 and the control samples was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Precisely, the XPS analysis of NC@950 confirmed the existence of C and N elements along with O (attributed to the aerial exposure) [54,55]. While the XPS survey of FAS-NSC@950 confirmed the coexistence of Fe, S, N, C, and O elements on the material surface [37,41], confirming the S incorporation from the iron-source. The same chemical composition is detected for FS-NSC@950, despite slight deviation in the atomic% of each element (Table S1 and Fig. S17). Moreover, it also concludes that the metallic Zn was completely removed during high-temperature pyrolysis as anticipated (Fig. S17d). The high-resolution C 1s XPS spectra of Fe-based samples exhibited three characteristic peaks corresponding to C=C/C–C, C–N/C–S, and C–O bonds, representing that the carbon network was doped with N and S atoms and was partially oxidized on the materials surface (Fig. S18). Specifically, the peak of C–N/C–S bond detected for FS-NSC@950 and FAS-NSC@950 is located at 0.55–0.6 eV binding energy, higher than the C–N peak detected in NC@950, confirming the existence of N/S-dual-doped carbon support (Table S2). Furthermore, the C=C/C–C peak in both FS-NSC@950 and FAS-NSC@950 has been observed at a binding energy approximately 0.4–0.45 eV higher than that of NC@950. This observation confirms a higher degree of defect formation, aligning with the Raman analysis and indicating the presence of disordered carbon in FAS-NSC@950 [47,50]. Similarly, the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra exhibited characteristic peaks corresponding to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and surface oxidized-N species in NC@950 (Fig. S18b), while a new peak related to metal-N bonding was detected in the Fe-based samples (Fig. 2d–f and Table S3). Notably, all these peaks slightly shifted to higher binding energies, indicating synergistic interactions with the associated nanoparticles. Notably, FAS-NSC@950 exposed a relatively small quantity of Fe-N x sites (22.93%) than FS-NSC@950 (25.91%), possibly attributed to the abundant existence of FeS nanoparticles on the material surface. However, the ORR active Fe-N x sites (27.64%) were largely exposed after extensive acid washing (FAS-NSC@950-AW, Table S4). According to the recent research investigations, electrocatalysts with improved pyridinic-N and graphitic-N content can boost the ORR activity [56,57], as the former enhances oxygen adsorption capacity and the latter positively influences the electronic structure of the material [44]. Notably, the FAS-NSC@950 sample has the highest probability of graphitic-N content over the other control samples. Moreover, the relative proportion of pyrrolic-N was the highest in FAS-NSC@950, which can induce topological defects in the carbon network and influence the local electronic distribution, leading to improved oxygen adsorption [58]. The high-resolution S 2p XPS spectra of FAS-NSC@950 displayed the anticipated Fe–S bonding peak at 161.76 eV, confirming the presence of FeS nanoparticles [24]. It also confirmed the S-doping in the carbon network (Fig. 2g), as evidenced by two characteristic peaks related to C–S (163.68 eV) and S–S (164.97 eV) bonding. Additionally, surface oxidized S–O bonded peaks were detected at 167.96 and 169.17 eV due to the unavoidable aerial exposure. As anticipated, after the harsh acid leaching, the intensity of Fe–S bonding peak was reduced, indicating the removal of a small portion of weekly associated FeS nanoparticles from the material (Fig. 2h). Evidently, the XPS survey spectrum of FAS-NSC@950-AW displays slightly reduced S and Fe content (Table S1 and Fig. S19a). In the case of FS-NSC@950, except for the Fe–S bonding peak (Fig. 2i), all other peaks were observed in S 2p XPS spectrum. The unambiguous existence of C–S and S–S bonding peaks confirmed the effective incorporation of S atoms in the carbon network, resulting in N/S-co-doped carbon support. Furthermore, the Fe 2p XPS spectrum of FAS-NSC@950 showed the Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 regions with three deconvoluted peaks (Fig. S19b), corresponding to Fe2+ (708.33 and 720.8 eV), Fe3+ (711.23 and 724.97 eV) oxidation states, and shake-up satellite peaks (714.58 and 729.07 eV). Despite slight deviation in Fe content on the materials surface, the Fe 2p XPS spectrum of FAS-NSC@950-AW resembled the XPS spectrum of FAS-NSC@950 (Fig. S19c). On the other hand, Fe0 peak (707.04 and 720.87 eV) was clearly observed in Fe 2p XPS spectrum of FS-NSC@950 (Fig. S19d), in addition to deconvoluted Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 regions. Both the Fe2+ and Fe3+ peaks of FAS-NSC@950 were located at smaller binding energies, when compared to the locations in FS-NSC@950, indicating that the associated FeS nanoparticles are inducing the electron-rich Fe-N x sites for better oxygen adsorption/desorption kinetics [24]. Furthermore, the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) investigation of FAS-NSC@950 confirmed the smallest metallic content (Fig. S20), which is one of the lowest metallic contents among the recently reported Fe-based SACs; precisely the Fe wt% (weight percentage) detected in FAS-NSC@950 was 0.34% and the S wt% detected was 0.48% [44,59,60]. 3.2 Electrocatalysis 3.2.1 Oxygen reduction reaction The ORR activity of electrocatalysts was evaluated by rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements in oxygen-saturated alkaline KOH electrolyte (0.1 M). Initially, the catalysts-loaded electrodes were subjected to cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests in both oxygen- and nitrogen-saturated electrolyte. The CV test was used to activate the catalyst material in O2-saturated electrolyte, and the appearance of a sharp reduction peak confirmed its ability of oxygen reduction (Fig. 3 a and Figs. S21a–S27a). Subsequently, the same electrodes were used to test the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in order to determine the actual ORR activity at speed of 1600 r min−1 in O2-saturated KOH (Fig. 3b and Figs. S28 and S29). Notably, FAS-NSC@950 displayed a distinct reduction peak in O2-saturated KOH which was absent in N2-saturated KOH, confirming its ORR activity. Moreover, the LSV measurements confirmed its remarkable ORR activity, as it showed a more positive onset potential (E onset = 1.03 V) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.871 V) compared to the other catalysts fabricated in this study. These values were superior to those of the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (E onset = 0.987 V and E 1/2 = 0.84 V) and are comparable with most of the benchmark ORR catalysts (Fig. 3c and Tables S5 and S6). However, the sample prepared by treating ferrous sulfate and subsequent carbonization (FS-NSC@950) exhibited a competitive onset potential (E onset = 1.0 V) compared to FAS-NSC@950. Still, the half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.767 V) is considerably low, possibly due to the bare Fe nanoparticles that might hinder the exposure of active Fe-N x sites or lead to agglomeration. This is less likely in FAS-NSC@950 since the FeS nanoparticles are appropriately fixed in static locations within the graphitic carbon layers. Conversely, the strategy of removing FeS nanoparticles (FAS-NSC@950-AW) did not enhance the ORR activity; instead, it resulted in a 35 mV reduction in the E 1/2 value compared to FAS-NSC@950 [49]. This reduction suggests the essential role of FeS nanoparticles in improving the ORR. Fig. 3(d) and Fig. S12 confirm the possible leaching of a small portion of FeS nanoparticles, despite being protected by graphitic layers, owing to the harsh and extended acid treatment. The significant difference in performance observed after acid leaching underscores the importance of the appropriate presence of FeS nanoparticles and their synergistic interactions with Fe-N x sites [61]. According to the XPS spectral data, the relative proportion of Fe-N x sites in both FS-NSC@950 and FAS-NSC@950-AW was higher than that of the optimized catalyst (FAS-NSC@950, Table S4). However, they displayed relatively low ORR performance, confirming the crucial role of the associated nanoparticles in catalysis. Recent research approaches have confirmed that these associated nanoparticles can finely tune the electronic structure of M-N x sites, facilitating O2 adsorption kinetics, and extensive elimination of such nanoparticles results in mediocre ORR performance [28,45,49,62]. Specifically, a recent experimental and theoretical study by Zhang et al. established that a moderate amount of associated particles can significantly alter the electronic structure of Fe-N4 sites, resulting in breaking the symmetric charge distribution for greatly improved ORR [49]. Therefore, owing to the well-defined CNT network with embedded FeS nanoparticles which enhances electrical conductivity and the etched microrod surface that can facilitate the exposure of active site and improve the contact with the electrolyte, FAS-NSC@950 surpassed all the aforementioned samples and most of the recently reported iron-based ORR catalysts (Tables S5 and S6). Despite the variations in performance, it is important to note that the diffusion limiting current density (J d) differs among the aforementioned samples (Fig. 3c). Specifically, the growth of FeS nanoparticles enhanced the J d value compared to the sample with Fe nanoparticles. Interestingly, acid leaching slightly improved the J d value of FAS-NSC@950. Afterwards, in view of elucidating the reaction kinetics of as-prepared catalysts, Tafel slopes were derived from the corresponding LSV plots. In principle, smaller Tafel slope indicates the better reaction kinetics. It is noteworthy that FAS-NSC@950 exhibited a significantly smaller Tafel slope (52.2 mA cm−2) compared to the control samples and Pt/C (54.6 mA cm−2), indicating more favorable ORR kinetics (Fig. 3e and Figs. S28b and S29b). Afterwards, in view of elucidating the Fe-Phen incorporation phenomenon, HUT-11 was directly carbonized without treating with Fe-Phen, and even then, considerable performance was noticed (NC@950, E 1/2 = 0.692 V), although the precursor HUT-11 did not show any activity, possibly owing to the existence of N-doped graphitic carbon network (Fig. 3f and Fig. S28). The performance was further improved by treating HUT-11 with ammonium sulfate, as it can improve the N content and introduce additional dopant, S. As a result, the E 1/2 positively shifted by 51 mV, in addition to the enhancement of limiting current density (NSC@950, E 1/2 = 0.743 V) [44]. According to SEM analysis, it was evident that the surface of NSC@950 was considerably etched by the in situ released ammonia gas, in addition to the S doping, resulting in the significantly boosted ORR performance. This observation endorses that the N and S doping taking place in FAS-NSC@950, in addition to the surface etching by in situ generated NH3 gas, is highly beneficial for the greatly boosted ORR, when compared to FS-NSC@950, where only N-doping is taking place and barely not any surface etching occurs. On the other hand, the ORR capabilities of samples prepared by the treatment with different amounts of FAS-based Fe-Phen have also been compared. Evidently, the other FAS-based controlled samples with associated FeS nanoparticles also showed the better ORR performance than the Fe nanoparticles implanted FS-NSC@950 sample. Specifically, FAS(0.1)-NSC@950 (E 1/2 = 0.814 V) and FAS(0.3)-NSC@950 (E 1/2 = 0.808 V) displayed significantly better onset and half-wave potentials, but they are relatively low compared to the FAS-NSC@950 (Fig. 3f and Fig. S29). Despite displaying the smaller E 1/2 value, FAS(0.3)-NSC@950 exhibited slightly better limiting current density, demonstrating that the increase in Fe-Phen content facilitated the electric conductivity, as a result of the increase in the growth of conductive CNT. On the other hand, it should be noted that the optimized FAS-NSC@950 electrocatalyst displayed the most feasible ORR kinetics compared to all other electrocatalysts fabricated in this study, and it was comparable with most of the state-of-the-art ORR electrocatalysts reported recently [30]. To gain further insights into ORR kinetics, LSV tests were conducted at different rotation speeds, ranging from 400 to 2500 r min−1 (Fig. 3g and Figs. S30–S35). Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots were then derived from the LSV data and estimated the electron transfer number (n), as ORR can occur via a two-electron transfer mechanism (H2O2 production) or a four-electron transfer mechanism (H2O production) [63]. The obtained n value for FAS-NSC@950 confirmed a four-electron transfer ORR mechanism (Fig. 3h), which is similar to the commercial Pt/C (Fig. S30). The four-electron transfer mechanism, leading to selective H2O production rather than H2O2, was further evaluated through rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) experiments at 1600 r min−1. As displayed in Fig. 3(i), both FAS-NSC@950 and 20 wt% Pt/C exhibited a H2O2 production percentage of approximately 5% and the n value was four, confirming the four-electron transfer mechanism. In contrast, FS-NSC@950 displayed relatively lower selectivity towards H2O production, with a H2O2 yield percentage of around 20% and n value of 3.7, similar to the value obtained from its K-L plots. Some pioneering research studies have revealed that the single-atom sites coordinated by pyrrolic-N mostly proceed through two-electron transfer ORR mechanism, while ones coordinated by pyridinic-N facilitate the four-electron transfer mechanism [63]. Therefore, it is believed that the high pyrrolic-N content detected for FAS-NSC@950 potentially existed in the form of topological defects rather than coordinating with Fe. On the other hand, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), which signifies the availability of catalytic sites, was estimated utilizing the double-layer capacitance (C dl) data obtained by CV conducted within a non-Faradic capacitive current range (Fig. 4 a). This parameter provides valuable information about the catalytic sites accessible on the material, contributing to a comprehensive assessment of its electrochemical activity. Generally, a higher ECSA often correlates with increased catalytic activity, signifying the availability of more active sites for reactions. Notably, FAS-NSC@950 exhibited impressive C dl value (9.15 mF cm−2) in comparison to control samples, including NC@950 (2.8 mF cm−2), NSC@950 (5.0 mF cm−2), and FS-NSC@950 (6.84 mF cm−2). This substantial increase in C dl for FAS-NSC@950 indicates enhanced ECSA, exposing a larger number of catalytic sites for improving performance (Fig. S36). What is more, the long-term sustainability of a catalyst in a harsh electrolyte is a key parameter in real-world applications. Therefore, the stability of FAS-NSC@950 was initially assessed through continuous CV cycling test, and the results are shown in Fig. 4(b). The acquired LSV plots after continuous 1000 and 2000 CV cycles are nearly identical to the original LSV curve (ΔE 1/2 = 10 mV), confirming its superior stability [28,64]. Furthermore, the durability of FAS-NSC@950 and Pt/C was assessed by performing a chronoamperometric i-t test overnight at 1600 r min−1. As seen in Fig. 4(c), FAS-NSC@950 retained 95% of its initial current, while commercial Pt/C retained only 87% of its initial current, demonstrating the exceptional long-term operability of FAS-NSC@950. Similarly, the methanol tolerance nature of FAS-NSC@950 and Pt/C was assessed by injecting methanol (20 and 1 mL, respectively) into KOH electrolyte (90 mL). FAS-NSC@950 exhibited very high tolerance to methanol, as evidenced by the fact that it showed little to no current density deviation even after 20 mL of methanol addition, whereas Pt/C showed over 14% divergence after injecting only 1 mL of methanol (Fig. 4d). Besides, the CV and LSV plots of FAS-NSC@950, obtained after injecting methanol, exhibited a minimal deviation from their respective initial curve, confirming its superior methanol crossover behavior (Fig. 4e and f). The enhanced durability and methanol tolerance of FAS-NSC@950 can be attributed to FeS@C core-shell structure. In this configuration, the graphitic layers act as a protective barrier, preventing the leaching or contamination of the FeS nanoparticles by methanol. As a result, the stable FeS@C nanoparticles contribute to maintaining the performance of the Fe-N x sites throughout long-term catalysis [65]. 3.2.2 Oxygen evolution reaction In addition to superior ORR performance, the catalysts derived from HUT-11 displayed considerable OER activity in the same electrolyte. As presented in Fig. 5 (a), FAS-NSC@950 demonstrated much better OER activity compared to FS-NSC@950 and the commercial RuO2 electrocatalysts [25,43]. To be precise, the onset overpotential (E onset) required for FAS-NSC@950 is significantly small (229 mV) compared to the other two samples. Captivatingly, it requires 314 mV overpotential to accomplish the benchmark current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Ej =10), which is 19 mV lower than RuO2 and 34 mV lower than FS-NSC@950 (Fig. 5b). Moreover, it displayed a low Tafel slope of 60.64 mV dec−1, indicating the feasible OER kinetics compared to the other two catalysts (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to comprehend the solution resistance and the interactions at the electrode/electrolyte interface (Fig. 5d and Fig. S37). Owing to the in situ growth of conductive CNTs embedded with conductive FeS nanoparticles, FAS-NSC@950 exhibited the lowest charge-transfer resistance of 42.5 Ω, compared to the Fe nanoparticles associated microrods sample (FS-NSC@950, 93.43 Ω) and the other control samples, including NSC@950 (182.46 Ω) and NC@950 (245.2 Ω). Subsequently, stability tests, such as CV cycling and chronoamperometric i-t testing, were conducted to evaluate the long-term OER operational performance of FAS-NSC@950 (Fig. 5e and inset). Notably, the OER polarization curve obtained after 1000 CV cycles showed only a minor deviation from its initial curve, with a slight increase in the required overpotential to reach the benchmark of Ej =10 [43]. Moreover, the durability of FAS-NSC@950 was further assessed by operating i-t test at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 for a two-day period. Even under these conditions, the loss in current density was just 7%, while the commercial RuO2 lost twice current density in the control experiment. This signifies the remarkable durability of FAS-NSC@950. Additionally, a critical parameter indicating the efficiency of a bifunctional electrocatalyst is the bifunctional activity indicator ΔE, which can be calculated by determining the potential gap between OER and ORR (ΔE = Ej =10 − E 1/2). Interestingly, FAS-NSC@950 displayed the best ΔE value of 0.673 V (Table S7) [50,66], which is considerably better than the commercial Pt/C-RuO2 combination (Fig. 5f). In most SACs, the M-N x sites act as the real active sites for both ORR and OER. However, active sites detection become complicated when the M-N x sites are associated with other metallic species [45,67]. Recent literature studies have confirmed that M-N x sites act as the ORR active site, while the associated metallic species function as the OER active site [20,50]. Nevertheless, when these metallic species are covered by multiple-layered graphitic carbon, they are not expected to be directly available for intermediates formation, and thus they are not treated as the direct active sites [68,69]. To investigate the real active sites for both ORR and OER, samples after respective CV cycling tests were analyzed by XRD, SEM, and XPS. Powder XRD patterns confirmed the sustained existence of FeS nanoparticles (Fig. S38) without any noticeable phase transformation on a bulk scale after both ORR and OER. Morphology investigation supported the presence of FeS nanoparticles in CNT-attached nanorods (Fig. S39). Nanorods morphology and their surface were barely altered after ORR, while some nanorods surfaces were shielded by a thin layer after OER catalysis, resulting in a smooth surface [70]. Analysis of Fe 2p spectra showed no detectable change after the CV cycling test for ORR, confirming catalyst stability. However, a significant positive shift was detected after CV cycling for OER, confirming oxide/oxyhydroxide intermediate formation (Fig. S40). Despite this, N 1s XPS spectra displayed a consistent relative percentage of Fe-N x sites after ORR, with a small reduction after OER, indicating almost unchanged Fe-N x sites exposure on the surface of FAS-NSC@950 (Fig. S41a–c). S 2p XPS spectra demonstrated the emergence of oxidized peaks (S–O) after catalysis, with an 18.45% increase after ORR and 23.65% increase after OER (Fig. S41d–f). Recent studies have documented that the oxidized surface with C-SO x -C units adjusts surface electronic states of Fe-N x sites, promoting ORR [24]. Therefore, it is believed that FeS@C nanoparticles remain stable on nanorods surface, even after electrolysis, owing to the protective graphitic layer (core-shell structure), while the Fe–S peak attenuation could be attributed to the formation of in situ-grown oxidized surface layer. In summary, the Fe-N x sites play a crucial role in initiating the OER process, which is facilitated by synergistic interactions with associated FeS@C nanoparticles. The in situ-formed oxide/oxyhydroxide layer undergoes the remaining OER steps. For ORR, Fe-N x sites are the primary contributors to catalytic activity, with associated nanoparticles and in situ-formed C-SO x -C units further facilitating the process. Theoretical investigations on nanoparticles-associated Fe-N4 models have also established that the O2 adsorption and the formation of subsequent reaction intermediates become feasible in such composite catalysts, compared to the Fe-N4 models [71,72], emphasizing the significance of the co-existence of Fe-N x sites and FeS nanoparticles in FA-NSC@950. Therefore, it is concluded that the Fe-N x sites in FAS-NSC@950 are the real active sites initiating the catalysis, and the associated FeS nanoparticles regulate the surface structure of Fe-N x sites for facilitating O2 adsorption/desorption kinetics, resulting in the better bifunctional activity. 3.3 Zinc-air battery assembly As-prepared FAS-NSC@950 was employed as the air cathode in assembling the zinc-air battery (ZAB) in order to showcase its potential of real-world applications, considering the remarkable ORR and OER activity. Specifically, a lab-made ZAB was constructed by combining a FAS-NSC@950 cathode and a zinc plate anode in an alkaline electrolyte comprising of 6 M KOH and 0.02 M Zn(OAc)2 (Fig. 6 a) [73]. A considerably better open circuit voltage of 1.48 V was detected for the FAS-NSC@950-based ZAB, outpacing the Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB (1.44 V) (Fig. 6b) [20]. Additionally, the significantly better power density (181.8 mW cm−2) and a high specific capacity (793.28 mA h g−1, based on the consumed Zn weight) were observed for the FAS-NSC@950 battery (Fig. 6c and d), outperforming the Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB (power density: 158.3 mW cm−2 and specific capacity: 765.4 mA h g−1). While the specific capacity of zinc-air batteries is generally influenced by the Zn anode, the higher specific capacity of FAS-NSC@950 cathode can be attributed to its exceptional bifunctional electroactivity. The enhanced ORR and OER activities of FAS-NSC@950 contribute not only to cathodic performance but also influence the overall efficiency of the zinc-air battery. To address the complex interplay between the cathode and anode, a mechanical recharge was performed by replacing the zinc anode and refuelling the electrolyte in the FAS-NSC@950 battery. Importantly, the voltage detected after each recharge process remained consistently high, emphasizing its remarkable performance (Fig. 6e) [67]. Moreover, galvanostatic charge-discharge cycling tests were carried out at 10 mA cm−2 on both FAS-NSC@950 and Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZABs in view of elucidating their cycling stability (Fig. 6f) [49,74]. Captivatingly, the FAS-NSC@950-based ZAB exhibited exceptional rechargeability, demonstrating minimal variation in the voltage profile even after 350 continuous charge-discharge cycles over a period of 3 days. The round-trip efficiency remained notably high, with a 60.88% detection during the first cycle and a slight decrease to 54.96% (i.e., approximately 9.5% drop) after the extensive cycling period. Moreover, it is important to note a very small overpotential requirement of 0.753 V (potential gap) during the initial stages, which slightly increased to 0.877 V after continuous charge-discharge cycling tests (Fig. S42). In comparison, the Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB displayed a considerably smaller round-trip efficiency (57%) with a 0.845 V overpotential requirement initially, which was mostly significant until 110 charge-discharge cycles (∼28 h) with a considerable deviation in round-trip efficiency (51.03%, Fig. S43) and a slight improvement in overpotential requirement (potential gap of 1.04 V). However, the performance significantly dropped after 28 h of operation, with a substantial gap in potential requirement and an extensive drop in round-trip efficiency. The zoomed-in views of cycling data at the beginning, after 24 h (Fig. 6g and h), and at different time intervals (Figs. S42 and S43) clearly demonstrate the superiority of the FAS-NSC@950-based ZAB over the commercial Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB. The excellent round-trip efficiency detected for FAS-NSC@950, together with its noteworthy power density and specific capacity, establishes it as one of the finest non-noble metal-based alternatives reported recently. These findings underscore the practical viability and superiority of FAS-NSC@950 in real-world ZAB applications. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a new metal-organic framework precursor was employed as a sacrificial template to fabricate iron SACs with Fe-N x sites associated core-shell FeS nanoparticles. Through the effective regulation of the iron source used during the adsorption process, a conductive N/S-doped mesoporous carbon with abundant Fe-N x sites and embedded core-shell FeS nanoparticles, alongside an in situ grown carbon nanotubes network, was prepared (FAS-NSC@950). Leveraging the inherit properties of the MOF, the in situ growth of conductive CNTs with embedded FeS nanoparticles, a significantly high ECSA, a small charge transfer resistance, improved topological defects, and effective synergistic interactions between Fe-N x sites and the core-shell FeS nanoparticles, the resulting FAS-NSC@950 catalyst demonstrated remarkable bifunctional activity (ΔE = 0.673 V) and delivered substantial performance in ZAB applications. Controlled experiments revealed that the FeS nanoparticles, by regulating the kinetics of oxygen adsorption, are indeed essential for enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. This study presents a significant advancement in the rational design of non-noble metal-based bifunctional electrocatalysts, offering promising prospects for the development of efficient and cost-effective energy conversion and storage technologies. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient single-atom catalysts (SACs) for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) remains a formidable challenge, primarily due to the symmetric charge distribution of metal single-atom sites (M-N4). To address such issue, herein, Fe-N x sites coupled synergistic catalysts fabrication strategy is presented to break the uniform electronic distribution, thus enhancing the intrinsic catalytic activity. Precisely, atomically dispersed Fe-N x sites supported on N/S-doped mesoporous carbon (NSC) coupled with FeS@C core-shell nanoparticles (FAS-NSC@950) is synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction and subsequent pyrolysis. Due to the presence of an in situ-grown conductive graphitic layer (shell), the FeS nanoparticles (core) effectively adjust the electronic structure of single-atom Fe sites and facilitate the ORR kinetics via short/long-range coupling interactions. Consequently, FAS-NSC@950 displays a more positive half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.871 V with a significantly boosted ORR kinetics (Tafel slope = 52.2 mV dec−1), outpacing the commercial Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.84 V and Tafel slope = 54.6 mV dec−1). As a bifunctional electrocatalyst, it displays a smaller bifunctional activity parameter (ΔE) of 0.673 V, surpassing the Pt/C-RuO2 combination (ΔE = 0.724 V). Besides, the FAS-NSC@950-based zinc-air battery (ZAB) displays superior power density, specific capacity, and long-term cycling performance to the Pt/C-Ir/C-based ZAB. This work significantly contributes to the field by offering a promising strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of SACs for ORR, with potential implications for energy conversion and storage technologies.
